summary_generated: Veterans' Education and Training Act of 1994 - Makes technical and conforming amendments to Federal provisions concerning: (1) active duty training; (2) the reserve program; (3) training and rehabilitation for veterans with service-connected disabilities; (4) alternative teacher certification programs; (5) education outside the United States; (6) correspondence courses; and (7) approval of programs of education.
predicted_summary: Veterans Education and Training Act of 1994 - Amends the U.S. Marine Corps' Education, Training, and Materials Act to require the Secretary of the Army, upon request, to provide training for active duty and reserve personnel in the Marine Corps. Specifies that training shall be conducted in accordance with specified requirements.Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide training and rehabilitation for veterans with service-connected disabilities.Requires the Veterans' Benefits Act of 1992 (VA) to extend through 1996 the veteran's benefits program through FY 1995. (Sec. 3)Veterans Educational Supplement Act of 2003 - Amends the Education Act to require the Secretary of Education to approve any correspondence course offered by an educational institution in a State unless such institution is an approved institution of higher learning and the course is approved by the Secretary.Amends the title to: (1) extend the program of education exclusively by correspondence and (2) establish a correspondence-residence course (CEET) commencing after 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act; and (3) provide for reimbursement for the costs of such courses.Requires agencies to report to Congress with respect to: (1) services provided after September 30, 1994, and (2) performance of agency personnel under such Act; and (3) evaluation of agency performance. (4) Requires agencies, after the end of such a fiscal year, to report annually to Congress on agency performance and performance.Requires training programs to: (1) enroll training participants in the community for an entire period of training; and (2) provide training in schools and local government for such training completion.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Secretary of Labor, upon receipt of a notice of employment, to administer two or more programs of job training for an eligible person. (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Secretary to: (1) administer training for such eligible person in two or three programs of employer-approved training; and (2) notify the eligible person's employer within one year after the date on which such notice is transmitted to the employer.Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives to: (1) elect a new Clerk of the Senate, and (2) establish a committee to advise the President on the appropriateness of the bill.

summary_generated: Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1997 - Amends Federal law to provide that any service as a Member of Congress of an individual convicted of specified offenses committed while a Member during the 105th Congress or later, if the conduct on which the offense is based is directly related to the individual's service as a Member, shall not be taken into account as creditable service for purposes of annuity or retirement provisions. Entitles such individual (or his or her beneficiary or estate, if applicable) to be paid so much of such individual's lump-sum credit as is attributable to such service.
predicted_summary: Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to pay certain civil service retirement benefits to such members of the U.S. Congress who have violated the public trust and are not held liable for their actions. Requires the Administrator of the National Labor Relations Act (NLRB) to administer the NLSA, the National Retirement System of the United States, and the National Pension System (NPSR) in the event of a civil service discharge.Prohibits such offenses from being construed to be criminal acts committed while a member of the House of Representatives or the Senate.Directs the Secretary of Labor to investigate and report to Congress on: (1) employee recruitment; (2) subject to Federal election laws; and (3) subjecting certain Federal election officials (FECs) to a tax penalty.Imposes criminal penalties for: (1) false denial of commission of a crime; and (2) interference with commerce by threats or violence.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) require the Secretary of the Treasury to prescribe such regulations as may be necessary to carry out this Act; and (2) require such regulations to be prescribed by the Secretary with respect to the Thrift Savings Plan, the Federal Employees Retirement System (FRS), and the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Administration (FERS).Requires an individual convicted of an offense to be eligible to participate in the retirement system while a member.

summary_generated: (This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 12, 2016. Know Before You Fly Act (Sec. 2) This bill makes it an unfair or deceptive practice for any air carrier, foreign air carrier, or ticket agent to fail to include, in an internet fare quotation for a specific itinerary in air transportation selected by a consumer, a clear statement that additional fees for checked baggage and carry-on baggage may apply, along with a prominent link from that internet website page directly to a list of all such fees. (Sec. 3) A "covered air carrier" (an air carrier that provides scheduled or public charter passenger air transportation by operating an aircraft that as originally designed has a passenger capacity of 30 or more seats) shall publish on its public internet website, via a prominent link on its website, a clear statement indicating whether or not it will: (1) provide for hotel accommodations, (2) arrange for ground transportation, (3) provide meal vouchers, (4) arrange for air transportation on another air carrier or foreign air carrier to the passenger's destination, and (5) provide for sleeping facilities, food, and water inside the airport terminal. The information provided by a covered air carrier shall identify each air carrier and foreign air carrier with which it will arrange air transportation
predicted_summary: Directs the Administrator of the National Airports Association to report to Congress on fees, fees, expenses, and benefits for air carriers, foreign carriers, or ticket agents. (Sec. 3) This Act may be cited as the "Know Before You Fly Act".Authorizes a covered air carrier to: (1) provide for hotel accommodations; (2) arrange for air transportation to the passenger's destination; and (3) provide meal vouchers.Authorizes an Administrator of a Federal Aviation Administration (AIA) to: (1) modify, abridge, or repeal any obligation of an air carrier to suspend, cancel, or suspend operations as a result of computer systems or computer networks failure; or (2) suspend, suspend, or revoke any such obligation.Directs the Administrator of the National Civil Aviation Organization (NHA) to: (1) report to the Administrator with respect to a report received under subsection (A) that a corrective action would reduce the recurrence of an event described in the report; and (2) submit to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives a report on:  (1); how the report was received; and  how it was managed.

summary_generated: Establishes a Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001 Terrorist Attacks. Directs the Board to: (1) study matters relating to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Centers in New York and the Pentagon, and the hijackings which proceeded the attacks; and (2) report to Congress on its work and its recommendations for legislation and administrative actions.
predicted_summary: Directs the Board of Inquiry to investigate the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.Directs the Board to conduct a thorough study of all relevant intelligence-related matters relating to the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the World Trade Centers in New York and the Pentagon and to determine what systemic problems in the collection, analysis, or dissemination of intelligence, or counter-terrorism, need to be corrected to prevent further terrorist attacks.Sets forth procedures for the work of the Board under this Act. (Sec. 3) The Board shall, after the first meeting of the board, report to Congress a preliminary report setting for a plan for the board's work. (A preliminary report may include recommendations for legislation and administrative actions as it considers appropriate.)Directs the Attorney General to: (1) request a subpoena issued by the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New Jersey (SDSN) to be paid from funds available to pay the expenses of the subpoenaed person; and (2) make such person available to the public at any designated place to appear or to produce documentary or other evidence.Authorizes the Board to: (1) accept, use, and dispose of gifts or donations of services or property; and (2) dispose of such items if they are used in the performance of the Board's duties.Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to procure temporary and intermittent services at rates below the daily equivalent of the federal government's basic pay for employees who do not possess such clearance.Requires the Secretary of the Treasury, upon transfer to the National Archives and Records Administration, to report to the Secretary with respect to any information obtained, examined, or otherwise reviewed by the Board.Authorizes appropriations through FY 2002. Authorizes the appropriation of $1.5 billion for FY 2002 to carry out this Act.

summary_generated: Transparency and Accountability of Failed Exchanges Act - Amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to require a state that is awarded a grant to establish an American Health Benefit Exchange (a health insurance exchange created under such Act) that terminates the operation of such Exchange or otherwise transfers the operation of it to an entity other than such state to: (1) submit to Congress and the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) a report containing the results of an audit of how amounts awarded to it pursuant to the grant were used; and (2) within 30 days after such termination or transfer, rescind any unobligated amounts awarded to it pursuant to the grant and require the state to provide to the Administrator of General Services any property acquired with such amounts, as well as submit to Congress and the Secretary a record of the provision of such property to the Administrator. Requires funds rescinded to be retained in the general fund of the Treasury for federal budget deficit reduction and allows the Administrator to dispose of any property obtained through a public auction for cash and for not less than its fair market value, as determined by the Administrator. Provides that such property shall not be subject to certain property disposal requirements.
predicted_summary: Transparency and Accountability of Failed Exchange Act - Amends Title XVIII of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (P&C) to require States awarded exchange establishment grants that terminate state operation of such exchange to provide audits of the use of grant funds and return funds to the federal government.Directs the Administrator of the General Services Administration (GSA) to: (1) rescind any unligated amounts awarded to such States pursuant to such grant; and (2) notify such State of the termination or transfer of any such property.Authorizes the Administrator of General Services to: (1) dispose of such property through a public auction for cash and for less than the fair market value of the property; (2) provide to any federal agency such property for official use by such agency; or (3) lease or hire such property, and may insure such property.Authorizes the Administrator to deposit any income from property obtained pursuant to this Act in the general fund of the Treasury for federal budget deficit reduction.Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Attorney General to bring an enforcement action against grants made before, on, or after the date of the enactment of this Act and to terminations and transfers of exchanges occurring before such on such date. (Sec. 3)
